comments.commentBody: People need to be told that a win must include wins in both houses of Congress. Must.

The real agenda of the Republican Party must remain unspoken. Since 1980 the reins of power within the GOP have been taken by the emerging plutocracy. The wealthy in this country have slipped from being a highly, and broadly, educated elite that was at least infected with some notion of oblesse oblige to a crass class of kleptocrats. The believe that the reason that they are wealthy is that they deserve it. (Thank you Ayn Rand!)

Further, they believe that their country owes them more to continue to receive the blessings that they bestow upon the rest of us.

The real agenda of the Republican Party is to bolster the fortunes of that class, to feed the greed of oligarchs.

I am sure that many Republican politicians who consider themselves the heart, soul, and (especially) brains of the GOP, folks like Paul Ryan and Rick Santorum, actually believe the pablum they spout. They believe that their "ideals" of smaller government (except for the government's right to police sexuality, according to folks of the Santorum wing) are what drive the GOP.

But come fund raising time, they take their orders from the real masters of the Republican Party.

And those folks have only one item on their agenda: cutting taxes for the wealthiest among us.

I wish I could believe that Republicans are simply wedded to the wrong economic ideas. But at the moment they have no actual, considered economic principles, save one: They oppose anything that will help the economy. That makes them evil Keynesians, fully aware that government spending alleviates a private-sector slump. and determined for that very reason to make sure it doesn't happen as long as a Democrat is president. Our current lineup is not quite smart enough to be labeled Nixonian, but they are following Nixon's principles. And if they win, they will employ them by pumping up government spending, enhancing  their prospects in 2014 and 2016 without regard to the deficit. Jeez, even George W. Bush was savvy  enough to do that. So they may be ignoramuses, but more important, they are saboteurs.They are much worse than you, Professor K, apparently think they are.
I just wanted to clarify that in my second sentence, the "too" is meant to relate back to Andrew Rosenthal's post, not to my own previous sentence.

I, "too," was impressed at Martha Raddatz setting limits and engaging in questions connected to the answers. I thought her question on religion addressed a private matter, but amazingly, it brought forth an important issue of public policy, the campaigns' views on reproductive rights.

Best debate since the New Hampshire non-major candidate, Democratic party debate with Vermin Supreme, who wears a boot on his head and promises a pony for every household to reduce foreign energy dependence. but makes it clear, he's for government-mandated tooth brushing--and funds for time travel.

My twitter stream read like a prize fight narrative: "punches," "booms," "call 911," and lots of quotes and holler-backs. Question: am I the only one to take note of Paul Ryan's moussed, 50s styled hair with the dated front roll?

Martha Raddatz is a prime example of what journalists should be doing. She is a professional, unlike many pundits on prime time television, and she makes an ideal role model for anyone considering serious journalism.

As I wrote elsewhere, I liked the questions towards the end of the debate through which Martha Raddatz required the candidates to do some thinking on their (metaphorical) feet.  I was impressed with how she handled her job, too.  She ended colloquies when she wanted to move on, for example, and she shepherded the flow of the discussion.
There's really no reason why you can't see both.  It's not a contest.
Thanks, Mr. Stuart, but I'll see the movie "Nashville" again before this. Nice satire anyway as 2012 vis-a-vis 1962!

Well said, David. I am a retired Air Force colonel, Vietnam vet, whose son served two Army tours in Iraq. Former SecDef Gates, who has my total respect, has stated that attacking Iran would bring on a catastrophe. I agree.

How easy it is to rattle your sabre when you and your loved ones lives are not at stake.

You really want to take out Iran to please the ultra orthodox loonies in Israel?

OK, to do the job right, let's have a formal declaration of war, re-institute the draft, raise taxes, and take out Israel's nukes at the same time.

Do we have a deal?

Vice President Biden is also the father of a US serviceman, his son Beau Biden. Unlike Romney or any of his sons.

From Wikipedia:
Biden joined the military in 2003 as a member of the Delaware Army National Guard and was recently promoted to the rank of Major in the Judge Advocate General (JAG) Corps as part of the 261st Signal Brigade in Smyrna, Delaware.

Biden's unit was activated to deploy to Iraq on October 3, 2008, and sent to Fort Bliss, Texas for pre-deployment training, the day after his father participated in the 2008 presidential campaign's only vice presidential debate. His father is on the record as saying, "I don't want him going. But I tell you what, I don't want my grandson or my granddaughters going back in 15 years, and so how we leave makes a big difference."

Biden traveled to Washington, D.C. from Iraq in January 2009 for the presidential inauguration and his father's swearing-in as Vice President, then returned to Iraq Biden returned from Iraq in September 2009, his yearlong deployment complete Biden had announced that during his deployment he would continue to actively serve as Delaware's Attorney General by working in conjunction with his office's senior staff in Delaware, although a member of his unit related Biden saying he had turned over most of his attorney general work to his deputy so as to focus on his duties in Iraq.
The military-industrial complex is what got us out of the Great Depression at the beginning of WW2!

Watching the debate tonight, Biden kept pressing Ryan how he would do things different in regards to Iran.

Now if you want a lesson in weaseling and obfuscation, just replay that portion of the debate. Ryan's obvious alternative is military action, and he made it plain that he and Romney would do everything they can to keep the military budget from taking any cuts.

We have been giving the rest of the world military aid for 57 years now. We have had troops in Europe and Asia since the end of WWII. Those countries have not had to spend a third of what would be needed to keep their own armed forces at the levels needed to replace U.S. troops.

As I have said many times, Ryan, Romney, if you want to fight, join up, and take your kids with you, then we will see just how badly you want to fight.

Biden made it plain what the administration's policy. It is your country, you defend it.
The unspoken alternative to the Iran problem is war, no matter how much denying that fact by Ryan.

VSP indeed are somewhat masochistic or else as most of the commentors have pointed out are working in their own very selfish self interests.  It is good to see they may realize their 1937 error and institute appropriate corrective stimulus.
I agree. When will we see polls that include a solid sample of cell phone users? The vast majority of those under 35 use only cell phones. Are they not a pretty sizable voter bloc?

Geez, dial back the vitriol.

And the nerve of her, wanting to hang out with her sister. (FYI, I'm pretty sure she knows whether her sister is a lesbian or not- I doubt she has to "presume" it from the fact she's not interested in kids).

Fifi, you are okay. Whatever is weighing on you, whatever you are running away from by posting something like this, I promise you it's not as bad as you think it is. But giving yourself over to this state of mind, and letting yourself post a comment like this... it's not good for you. You're venting your anger at a total stranger, instead of getting in touch with whatever's filling you with so much rage and unhappiness.

I'm so sorry you felt a need to say all of the above in a public forum, and I hope that there is someone in your life who can give you the comfort and support you deserve, but in the meantime, please know that, one internet stranger to another, I'm thinking of you and hoping today brings you some peace and joy.
Wow fifi....that article seems to have struck a nerve. Look inside yourself to find the source of all that wrath.

Seems to me that you need get a life.  If you really wanted a child, a ruptured appendix would not have stopped you - there are so many children in this world that could use a caring family.  But of course, I bet you are one of those many women who do not consider a child a child unless he/she carries your own blood.  You are an author?  Your article is full of self pity and cliche - hanging our with your sister and her friends who don't subject themselves to such "maternal" drive and anxiety? Oh, right - she has to be a lesbian! Seriously? And you consider united states is a country whose culture is centers around "family and children"?!  Are you kidding me?  Honestly, you need to get out more.  I mean, not just out of town where you were born.  Out of this country, out of this continent.  In the mean time, you can also look around more (for this, you don't have to leave town) how many elderly people are actually living with their kids and their grand kids and are actually being "taken care of" by their immediate families.  By the way, I am grateful that you don't have children.  Having chidren just so that you think they will and have to take care of you when you are old is the wrong reason to have kids, especially for this country!

You can't even begin to know the rewarding wonders of old age.

Only cowards commit suicide.

Maybe we should just all start drinking and smoking again, so often displayed in the Depression-era movies, so that we can die at a younger age of a quick heart attack rather than linger for years dependent upon others.

I doubt this will bring in the athlete vote or the women's vote.

Here in San Francisco, this photo shoot is perceived as a very gay layout, drawing big laughs...

I've lived in Alabama or Georgia all of my 58 years and your comments are so wrong as to be insidious.

The South started moving Republican immediately after passage of the Civil Rights Act in 1964. Alabama voted Republican in 1964 for the first time since the 1880's.

The Southern whites attitude concerning the Civil Rights Act led to Nixon's "Southern Strategy" concept.

As for the 1968 elections, why vote for Nixon when you've got George Wallace, the leading racist of his time. Humphrey only got 18% of the 1968 vote in Alabama, far from a split with Wallace.

What we've seen in the South since passage of Civil Rights is movement to the Republican Party, the growth of the Evangelical Movement, home schooling and christian academies to shelter their white children from blacks and now browns.

By the way... I'm white and it pains me that my people can be so stupid.
Although this comment is very sweet. Nick didn't even write this article, Micah Cohen did.

hey H. Carney! AMEN, I am there with you - just donated again and working at headquarters for the rest of the election. Get out and vote people - the stakes are too high to sit home and let these right-wingers take over our private lives. They can keep their religion in their own churches and let me run my life and my body. We see what happens around the world when people mix fundamentalist belief of any variety with government.
The two are not analogous.
Haven't seen those anywhere.  Can you point to a link?  Thanks!

Many GMOs are resistant to herbicides, not pesticides. It is true that herbicide-resistant weeds rapidly evolve, just as antibiotic-resistant bacteria show up rapidly.

Does this mean that we continuously pay royalties on antibiotics that no longer work? Of course not. We switch to different antibiotics.

Likewise, do we abandon antibiotics altogether even though evolution will always keep up with our tricks? That is a personal choice.

I chose to take antibiotics when I am sick, and thought I frequently eat organic foods when they're local, I have no problem with herbicide and pesticide-treated foods.

Nice article but you missed two important facets of this issue worth further investigation.

Monsanto is not only trying to prevent consumers from being able to make an informed decision on the demand side, they are also aggressively trying to eliminate the supply of the "alternative food chain" by exploiting a combination of contamination and patent litigation. GMO seeds drift under real world conditions, but when that drift occurs, not only is the alternative contaminated and ruined - and prevented from being able to sue Monsanto for damages caused by their seeds - the victims of this contamination are subsequently sued for patent infringement and forced to pay royalties for having GMOs found in their harvest. In South America, where the amounts are in the billions for royalties imposed on unwitting victims of contamination alone, this is known as the "Monsanto Tax".

The other factor is that GMOs are in a losing arms race with evolution. Many GMOs are designed to be resistant to pesticides. But natural selection has been evolving superbugs resistant to the pesticides Monsanto sells along with their seed. Thus more pesticides need to be used to have an effect, increasing the amount of pesticides in the food supply. Eventually they will be useless and the pesticide resistant GMOs will be pointless, yet pervasive if contamination is allowed to continue unchecked.

Farmers could be forced to continuously pay royalties on a GMO with no lasting practical benefit.
Nice screed fanatic.  Here's a tip,  the longer the post, the fewer that people read it.  Unless you're Nate.  And you're no Nate.
First impression?  He's been President of the United States for four years!
First impression?  He's been President for 4 years.

You can scratch Suffolk off the list of pollsters to take seriously from here on out. He may be correct about the three states, but none of his polling shows a Romney lead.

What is his basis for removing his pollsters, if not his own polls? The zeitgeist? He doesn't believe his own polling, so why should anyone else?
Boo.
You got your wish!
One more out, then game five. Let's go O's!
There is always hope, but where is A-Rod?
"America is not happy"  Faux populism, you may only speak for yourself.  One thing is for sure; TeaCongress approval rating 13%, America is not happy with them!

The volatility and swings of the polls sort of highlights how much this election is a "hold your nose" sort of affair, and how polarized everything has become.

America is not happy. Not with Obama, not with Romney either. Neither candidate inspires confidence, or really grabs their base.

So the choice seems to come down to who will suck least, and the perceptions surrounding that sentiment appears to be very fragile across the board.
